name: Borax
Relationship: Acetic acid, vinegar, and wine are incompatible. Antidote: Cham.; Coffea. Compare: Calc.; Bryon.; Sanicula; Sulph-ac.

Respiratory: Arrest of breathing when lying; is obliged to jump and catch breath, which causes pain in right side
Stitches in chest, with inspiration and cough
Hacking and violent cough; expectoration, mouldy taste and smell
Cough with mouldy taste - breath smells mouldy
Out of breath on going up stairs
Pleurodynia; worse upper part of right chest

Extreme anxiety, especially from motions which have a downward direction, rocking, being carried downstairs, laid down
Violent fright from report of a gun, even at a distance

Loose, pappy, offensive stools in children

Hair tangled at tips, cannot be separated, as in plica polonica

Mouth: Mouth hot and tender; ulcers bleed on touch and eating
Pain as if diarrhoea would result

Sensation of distention in clitoris with sticking
Menses too soon, profuse, with gripping, nausea and pain in stomach extending into small of back

Erysipelatous inflammation with swelling and tension

Cries out of sleep as if frightened

Eczema of toes and fingers with loss of nails
Feeling as of cobwebs on hands

details: Gastrointestinal irritation. Salivation, nausea, vomiting, colic, diarrhoea, collapse, albuminuria, casts and vesical spasm. Delirium, visual changes, hematuria, and skin eruptions have all be observed from over-dosing. DREAD OF DOWNWARD MOTION in nearly all complaints. For homeopathic purposes, the peculiar nervous symptoms are very characteristic, and have frequently been verified, especially in the therapeutics of children. Of much value in epilepsy. Aphthous ulceration of mucous membranes.
dosage: First to third trituration. In skin diseases continue its use for several weeks. Locally in pruritis pudendi. A piece of borax, the size of a pea, dissolved in the mouth, acts magically in restoring the voice, in cases of sudden hoarseness brought on by cold, and frequently for an hour or so, it renders the voice silvery and clear.
